subject: RE: [junit] checking for test coverage
msgSnippet: Ant has tasks for JProbe 3.0: jpcoverage, jpmerge, jpreport.  Works great if you have JProbe 3.0.  Prints out nice looking reports, similar to the HTML reports
messageBody:
Ant has tasks for JProbe 3.0: jpcoverage, jpmerge, jpreport. Works great if you have JProbe 3.0. Prints out nice looking reports, similar to the HTML reports from Ant's JUnit task. Actually somewhat more accurate coverage numbers because the Ant report task uses a reference classpath to do a delta of actual classes/bytes versus classes/bytes loaded by JProbe at runtime.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Chris Eppstein [mailto:ceppstein@...]
>
> Thanks to all for your replies. To recap:
>
> The filename matching system that David proposed was my first
> thought as
> well and it could be implemented as an Ant task easily enough
> so that can be
> used to fail a build if a test case is missing, etc... I had
> started to
> write this utility when I decided to email the list and make
> sure I wasn't
> re-inventing the wheel. I think that this approach is a good
> first step but
> it doesn't give us a look into the code and it would be
> difficult to handle
> interfaces (for which I rarely write a unit test).
>
> I looked at NoUnit but I cannot get it to run with Java 1.4
> -- it looks
> promising though. Quilt is the most ambitious of the open
> source projects
> and it also looks to be very promising -- but is still pre-alpha and
> probably not ready for use in a corporate setting.
>
> Integration with Ant is, of-course, a big plus for any
> utility that can be
> used for this task. Looks like there's some definate room for
> improvement in
> this area. Does anyone else have some suggestions?
>
> Chris
